Virtually all of the culture techniques discussed above rely, at some point, on <a1_0><b6_0>microscopic examination<b6_0/><a1_0/> for definitive identification of the infectious agent. Microscopy may be carried out with simple instruments, such as the compound <b7_0>light microscope<b7_0/>, or with instruments as complex as an electron microscope. Samples obtained from patients may be viewed directly under the <a2_0>light microscope<a2_0/>, and can often rapidly lead to identification. Microscopy is often also used in conjunction with biochemical staining techniques, and can be made exquisitely specific <a3_0><b8_0>when used in combination with antibody based techniques<b8_0/>.<a3_0/> For example, the use of antibodies made artificially fluorescent (fluorescently labeled antibodies) can be directed to <a4_0><b9_0>bind to and identify a specific antigens present on a pathogen<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
